awd_titl_txt: Infusing Learning Initiatives for Improving the Programming Proficiency of Computer Science Majors at Morgan State University
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program provides support to design, implement, study and assess efforts to increase the numbers of students and the quality of their preparation by strengthening science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and research. This project at Morgan State University provides a strategic approach to infuse learning initiatives into two computer science courses to increase students' proficiency and success  in programming skills with the goal to retain them as computer science majors. Undergraduate students are involved in this project as researchers. 

This one-year pilot project seeks to implement problem solving strategies involving programming to develop strategies that can enhance the students' ability to develop proficient critical thinking skills as they learn to program. The project will study the psycho-social
attributes that students exhibit towards programming using qualitative and quantitative measures. The project is guided by formative and summative evaluation and an advisory committee.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: This objective of this NSF award was to add to the knowledge regarding the adoption of two industry-based initiatives for improving programming proficiency and student learning in the Computer Science (CS) classroom: interactive whiteboard problem solving and coding reviews. Through these two initiatives, the intent was to enhance the students' computational and critical-thinking skill sets by equipping them with the ability to: 1) confidently develop solutions to computational problems by hand, 2) effectively analyze, review, and interpret written code solutions, 3) effectively communicate their developed computational skills in practical settings, and 4) develop proficient skills that will allow them to become more competitive candidates in the tech industry job market. 

Broader Impacts: This project evaluated the students' ability to acquire desirable programming skill sets that can enhance their ability to become more competitive candidates on the job market and advance in their careers in the tech industry. Such evaluations and outcomes can be employed by other CS departments in an effort to improve the retention and skill quality of their students. This project could also be of interest to related disciplines in STEM, especially if their students aspire to have a career tech. 

Key Findings & Outcomes: 

Interactive Whiteboard Problem Solving: The students' level of comfort with whiteboard problem solving tasks consistently increased over time, especially after completing a given assessment. 

Coding Reviews: Students were typically their strongest when reviewing procedural data structures and concepts, while their understanding of object-oriented data structure concepts was found to be their weakest aspect of these pedagogical reviews.

Psychosocial Dispositions: Students were found to exhibit improvements in their identity toward CS and self-efficacy toward programming during this project. Moreover, these students showed slight decreases in their anxiety towards programming over time. 


Products and Publications: Outcomes from this project has yielded two journal articles, five conference proceeding articles, and ten peer-reviewed student abstracts.


Student success: This project allowed 23 undergraduate students to serve as research assistants to the PI. These RAs were exposed to research skills comprised of: data analysis, literature reviews, abstract composition, and poster/oral disseminations of findings. As a result of this experience, many of these RAs were inspired to pursue their advanced degrees at the graduate level. Currently, 10 of these RAs have either enrolled or have completed their graduate studies (Master's program (9) and PhD program (1)), and 14 are now working in industry, government, or non-profit sectors. 


Last Modified: 04/25/2024
Modified by: Edward Dillon
